cosmology.name: The Great Wheel
cosmology.description: The default D&D cosmology includes more than two dozen planes. The most common understanding visualizes them as concentric wheels, with the material realms at the center. The Inner Planes form a wheel around the Material Plane, enveloped in the Ethereal Plane. The Outer Planes form another wheel around that one, arranged according to alignment, with the Outlands linking them all. Wildspace systems exist where the Astral Plane overlaps with the Material Plane, allowing access to the stars and planets of Material Plane worlds.

alternateConfigurations.name: World Tree
alternateConfigurations.description: Planes situated among the roots and branches of a great cosmic tree (literally or figuratively)

alternateConfigurations.name: Vertical Cosmology
alternateConfigurations.description: Material realms suspended between two other realities: the astral realms (the Astral Plane and the Outer Planes) above and the elemental realms (the Inner Planes) below

alternateConfigurations.name: Simplified Cosmology
alternateConfigurations.description: A cosmology with fewer planes: a Material Plane; the Transitive Planes; a single undifferentiated Elemental Plane; an Overheaven where good deities and Celestials dwell; and an Underworld where evil deities and Fiends reside

alternateConfigurations.name: Orbital Cosmology
alternateConfigurations.description: Planes arranged in a complex system of orbits, with planes exerting greater influence on the Material Plane the closer they draw to it

planeCategories.name: Material Realms
planeCategories.description: Most D&D worlds are located on the Material Plane, which has two planar echoes: the Feywild and the Shadowfell.

planeCategories.name: Transitive Planes
planeCategories.description: The Ethereal Plane and the Astral Plane are boundless realms that provide passage between other planes of existence.

planeCategories.name: Inner Planes
planeCategories.description: The four Elemental Planes (Air, Earth, Fire, and Water), plus the Para-elemental Planes between them.

planeCategories.name: Outer Planes
planeCategories.description: Seventeen Outer Planes correspond to the nine alignments and shades of philosophical difference between them.

planeCategories.name: Positive and Negative Planes
planeCategories.description: These two planes enfold the rest of the cosmology, providing the raw forces of life and death that underlie all existence in the multiverse.

planeCategories.name: Special Regions
planeCategories.description: Wildspace systems are regions where the Astral Plane overlaps with the Material Plane, containing the stars and planets of Material Plane worlds.

planes.name: Wildspace
planes.philosophicalEssence: Wildspace systems are vast expanses where the Astral Plane overlaps with the Material Plane, containing the celestial bodies—stars, planets, moons, gas clouds—of Material Plane worlds. Every world of the Material Plane is situated in a Wildspace system.
planes.emotionalInfluence: Unlike the rest of the Astral Plane, Wildspace does not suspend the passage of time or biological needs. Creatures and objects age normally and exist on both the Astral Plane and Material Plane simultaneously.

physicalProperties.shape: Vast airless expanses bobbing in the Astral Plane like corks in an ocean, each containing a sun, planets, moons, gas clouds, and other cosmic bodies
physicalProperties.atmosphereNotes: Wildspace systems are described as vast, airless expanses. Creatures require their own air supply or magical means to breathe. Space-dwelling life-forms (spores, plankton, larger creatures resembling fish and aquatic mammals) teem within Wildspace, suggesting pockets or envelopes of breathable atmosphere may exist around some bodies or creatures.

temperature.description: Temperature varies depending on proximity to the sun or other celestial bodies within the Wildspace system. No specific temperature is given in the rules.

physicalProperties.dominantElement: None; Wildspace is a void containing celestial bodies
physicalProperties.weatherPatterns: No weather patterns described; the environment is a void between celestial bodies

timeFlow.description: Unlike the rest of the Astral Plane where creatures don't age or suffer from hunger or thirst, creatures and objects in Wildspace age normally. This is because Wildspace exists on both the Astral Plane and Material Plane simultaneously, and the Material Plane's normal time flow applies.

hazards.name: Airless Void
hazards.description: Wildspace systems are vast, airless expanses. Creatures without their own air supply or magical means of breathing will suffocate. A creature can hold its breath for a number of minutes equal to 1 + its Constitution modifier (minimum of 30 seconds). When out of breath, it can survive for a number of rounds equal to its Constitution modifier (minimum 1 round), then drops to 0 HP and is dying until it can breathe again.
hazards.sourceReference: Wildspace description states 'vast, airless expanses'; suffocation rules from rules glossary

environmentalEffects.name: Dual Planar Existence
environmentalEffects.description: Creatures and objects in Wildspace exist on both the Astral Plane and Material Plane simultaneously.
environmentalEffects.mechanicalEffect: This overlap enables creatures to use spells such as Teleport to travel from Wildspace to a nearby world, or vice versa. Creatures and objects age normally in Wildspace, unlike in the rest of the Astral Plane where aging is suspended.

environmentalEffects.name: Normal Aging
environmentalEffects.description: Unlike the broader Astral Plane where creatures do not age or suffer from hunger or thirst, creatures in Wildspace age normally.
environmentalEffects.mechanicalEffect: Creatures and objects in Wildspace are subject to normal passage of time, hunger, thirst, and aging, because they exist on the Material Plane simultaneously. This is a specific exception to the Astral Plane's general rule that creatures don't age or suffer from hunger or thirst.

environmentalEffects.name: Astral Navigation to Wildspace
environmentalEffects.description: As an Astral traveler approaches a Wildspace system, the silver fog of the Astral Plane gradually thins until it falls away in Wildspace. Then the sun of the Wildspace system comes into view—often millions of miles away—along with colorful gas clouds, planets, moons, and other cosmic bodies.
environmentalEffects.mechanicalEffect: A creature in the Astral Plane can think of a specific Wildspace system (e.g., 'the Wildspace system of Realmspace') to become aware of the most direct route to that location. The creature does not know how long the journey will take or how perilous it will be, just which direction to go. The DM decides travel time; a trek to a specific Wildspace system might take 4d6 days.
environmentalEffects.sourceReference: Chapter 6: Cosmology, Astral Plane, Navigating the Astral Plane

environmentalEffects.name: Space-Dwelling Life-Forms
environmentalEffects.description: A Wildspace system teems with space-dwelling life-forms, including spores, plankton, and larger creatures that resemble fish and aquatic mammals.
environmentalEffects.mechanicalEffect: Encounters with space-dwelling creatures are possible while traveling through Wildspace. These life-forms populate the void between celestial bodies.

planarConnections.name: Wildspace to Astral Plane Boundary
planarConnections.description: Wildspace exists where the Astral Plane overlaps with the Material Plane. As an Astral traveler approaches a Wildspace system, the silver fog of the Astral Plane gradually thins until it falls away. A creature or ship traveling from one Wildspace system to another must cross the Astral Plane unless it has some other magical means of traveling from one world to another.
hazards: Psychic Wind while traversing the Astral Plane between Wildspace systems
navigableBy: Creatures using thought-based movement in the Astral Plane

planarConnections.name: Wildspace to Material Plane World
planarConnections.description: Every world of the Material Plane is situated in a Wildspace system. Because creatures in Wildspace exist on both the Astral Plane and Material Plane simultaneously, spells such as Teleport can transport creatures from Wildspace to a nearby world, or vice versa.

civilizations.name: Githyanki Outposts
civilizations.description: Githyanki establish outposts in Wildspace and on other planes so their children can grow to maturity, since creatures on the broader Astral Plane don't age.

specialRules.name: Astral Movement in Wildspace Approach
specialRules.description: While in the Astral Plane approaching Wildspace, a traveler can move by simply thinking about moving. In combat, a creature has a Fly Speed equal to 5 times its Intelligence score and can hover. Distance has little meaning outside combat.
specialRules.mechanicalEffect: Fly Speed (ft) = 5 × Intelligence score, with hover capability. To find a destination in or approaching Wildspace, a creature need only think about the destination (e.g., 'the Wildspace system of Realmspace') to become aware of the most direct route. The DM decides travel time: a trek to a specific Wildspace system might take 4d6 days; a more general location might take 1d4 × 10 hours.

specialRules.name: Inter-System Travel Requirement
specialRules.description: A creature or ship traveling from one Wildspace system to another must cross the Astral Plane unless it has some other magical means of traveling from one world to another.
specialRules.mechanicalEffect: There is no direct path between Wildspace systems; the Astral Plane must be traversed. This exposes travelers to Astral Plane hazards including psychic winds. Alternative methods include spells, the Shadowfell, or the Feywild, though such routes are less charted and no less perilous.

specialRules.name: Material-Astral Overlap Enables Teleportation
specialRules.description: Because creatures and objects in Wildspace exist on both the Astral Plane and Material Plane simultaneously, teleportation magic functions between Wildspace and nearby Material Plane worlds.
specialRules.mechanicalEffect: Creatures can use spells such as Teleport to travel from Wildspace to a nearby world, or vice versa. This is a specific property of the dual-planar overlap unique to Wildspace.

modifiedSpells.modification: Can be used to travel between Wildspace and a nearby Material Plane world due to the simultaneous existence on both planes
Can be used to travel between Wildspace and a nearby Material Plane world due to the simultaneous existence on both planes

adventureThemes: Exploration of cosmic voids between worlds
Discovery of distant Material Plane worlds

crossReferences.description: Contains extensive information about Wildspace and Astral travel
Wildspace is described as a subsection of the Astral Plane in Chapter 6: Cosmology. Also referenced under Material Plane section as a route for traveling between worlds (The Great Journey).

globalPlanarConnections.name: Astral Sea to Wildspace Systems
globalPlanarConnections.description: Wildspace systems bob in the Astral Plane like corks in an ocean. As an Astral traveler approaches a Wildspace system, the silver fog of the Astral Plane gradually thins until it falls away. Every world of the Material Plane is situated in a Wildspace system, making Wildspace the bridge between the Astral Sea and Material Plane worlds.

planarTravelMethods.name: Thought-Based Astral Travel to Wildspace
planarTravelMethods.description: A traveler in the Astral Plane can move by simply thinking about moving. To find a Wildspace system, the traveler thinks about the destination (e.g., 'the Wildspace system of Realmspace'), which makes the creature aware of the most direct route to that location. The creature doesn't know how long the journey will take or how perilous it will be, just which direction to go.
requirements: Must be on the Astral Plane
Must think of a specific Wildspace system or location within it
destinations: Any specific location within the Astral Plane or Wildspace

planarTravelMethods.name: Spelljammer Vessel Travel
planarTravelMethods.description: Traveling through Wildspace and across the Astral Plane aboard a vessel powered by magic is one method of transit between the worlds of the Material Plane (referred to as The Great Journey).
risks: Psychic Wind when crossing the Astral Plane between systems
destinations: Material Plane worlds within a Wildspace system

planarTravelMethods.name: Teleportation Between Wildspace and Material Plane Worlds
planarTravelMethods.description: Because creatures in Wildspace exist on both the Astral Plane and Material Plane simultaneously, teleportation spells can transport creatures from Wildspace to a nearby world, or vice versa.
requirements: Must be in Wildspace or on a nearby Material Plane world
risks: Standard risks of teleportation spells (e.g., off-target arrival)
destinations: Nearby Material Plane world from Wildspace
Wildspace from a Material Plane world

savingThrowProbabilities.formula: P(fail | modifier m) = max(0.05, min(0.95, (DC - 1 - m) / 20))
